item.title: Honkai: Star Rail – Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern Relic Guide
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern Relic In Honkai: Star Rail
  • How To Get Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern Relic In Honkai: Star Rail
  • Best Characters To Use Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern Relic Set In Honkai: Star Rail

When Honkai: Star Rail debuted, players were intrigued with the Break Effect system, but it never became meta as it was too tedious to be worth the time. Plus, playing on Auto basically messes the entire idea up. However, later on, HoYoverse attempts to make Break Effect a more relevant mechanic, starting by releasing Ruan Mei, who's the best character to bring if you're aiming to break the enemy's Toughness, then a Break Effect-centric character like Xueyi.

However, Break teams never truly became meta until the debut of Boothill, followed by Harmony MC and Firefly right after. Not only does Firefly hog the protagonist as her best support, but HoYoverse further spoils her by giving Firefly her own Relic Sets, which include the Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern. Fortunately, although it's designed for Firefly, Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern in Honkai: Star Rail is still viable for other characters.

Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern Relic In Honkai: Star Rail

Set

Effect

2pc Bonus

Increases the wearer's SPD by 6%. When the wearer hits an enemy target that has Fire Weakness, the wearer's Break Effect increases by 40%, lasting for 1 turn(s).

Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern Set is oddly specific about buffing characters that are hitting enemies with Fire Weakness. Although anyone can use it as long as the enemy has Fire Weakness, players will likely bring a Fire character in this scenario, indirectly making the Set mostly work for Fire units in Honkai: Star Rail .

The 40% Break Effect buff stays for one turn, which makes it even harder for the equipping character to do anything with this buff unless they’re targeting an enemy with Fire Weakness. Additionally, the Kalpagni Lantern gives 6% extra SPD, which, so far, is valuable for every Break DPS in Honkai: Star Rail . It's also viable for Support units that need to be fast.

How To Get Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern Relic In Honkai: Star Rail

Forge of Kalpagni Lantern in Honkai: Star Rail is obtainable from the Divergent Universe: Eternal Comedy stage. Unlike other Planar Ornaments, this Relic Set is unavailable in the normal Simulated Universe .

Best Characters To Use Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern Relic Set In Honkai: Star Rail

The Forge of the Kalpagni Lantern mostly works on Fire characters, since you’ll mostly use them when the enemy/boss has a Fire Weakness. For that, farm this Set if you have one of these characters.

Firefly

Firefly

Fire

Destruction

5-Star

Guides

Build Guide

Level-Up Materials

Team Composition

Best Light Cone

Just like the Iron Cavalry Against the Scourge Set, the Kalpagni Lantern was made for Firefly in Honkai: Star Rail . Not only is Firefly a Fire unit, but she’s also heavily reliant on SPD and Break Effect, which makes this Planar Ornament Set a perfect pick for her.

Gallagher

Gallagher

Fire

Abundance

4-Star

Guides

Build Guide

Level-Up Materials

Team Composition

Best Light Cone

Gallagher is a healer in Honkai: Star Rail who scales with Break DMG for his attacks and healing. Previously, before the release of Kalpagni Lantern, Gallagher's best Planar Ornament was Talia: Kingdom of Banditry. The Set gave him a 36% Break Effect on the condition of having more than 145 SPD. However, the Fire Abundance unit now has the Kalpagni Lantern set to grant him more SPD and Break Effect with an easier requirement to fulfill.

Himeko

Himeko

Fire

Erudition

5-Star

Guides

Build Guide

Level-Up Materials

Team Composition

Best Light Cone

Kalpagni Lantern unlocked a new, much improved Himeko in Honkai: Star Rail . This Himeko thrives at breaking Toughness before triggering her Talent’s passive and unleashing endless Ultimates and Follow-up attacks upon everyone. With Himeko’s ability to constantly keep attacking, building her with Kalpagni Lantern and Iron Cavalry Against the Scourge sets makes her perform as one of the best DPS in Honkai: Star Rail . Just make sure to bring Harmony MC along to ensure maximum damage.

Asta

Asta

Fire

Harmony

4-Star

Guides

Build Guide

Level-Up Materials

Team Composition

Best Light Cone

As a Harmony unit in Honkai: Star Rail , Asta’s buffs don’t scale with any of her stats, which makes her able to adopt a variety of builds. Add to this build's flexibility, Asta’s Skill, which can land multiple hits on the same target and can inflict some serious DMG if she has enough Break Effect. This is where Kalpagni Lantern becomes useful to Asta, since it also grants her 6% SPD on top of her Messenger Set’s 6% SPD. That could be perfect for any Harmony unit in Honkai: Star Rail .

item.title: Fallout 76: What Items Contain Gold? (And How To Farm Them)
item.description:
Gold is one of the many resources players can find while exploring the post-war ruins of Appalachia. It is a crafting component used to make things like energy weapons, serums, and various CAMP items.

While it's not as useful as components like lead and steel, gold still has its place in Fallout 76 . Despite not being as useful as some other components in the game, gold can be difficult to come by. Whether the player needs to scrap gold items as part of a challenge or they need gold for crafting, finding junk items that contain gold can be a bit tricky.

Items That Contain Gold In Fallout 76

While it can be hard to come by, there are a few items that contain gold scraps. Not only that but there's an enemy type that drops gold scraps when killed: Honey Beasts.

These creatures will normally drop 2 gold scraps when they are killed. While this number may vary, more often than not, a Honey Beast will drop some gold. As for the items that can be broken down for gold scrap, they can be seen in the table below:

Item

Gold Content

High Int Rock

2

Red Star Pin

1

Unstoppables! Board Game

1

Gold Table Spoon

1

Gold Table Knife

1

Gold Fork

1

Gold Plated Flip Lighter

1

Gold Pocket Watch

1

While these items can be found scattered throughout Appalachia, one of the easiest places to get gold in a hurry is the Whitespring Mall. There's a robot vendor called Helena. She sells an array of items that contain gold. Typically, she will sell a couple of Gold Plated Flip Lighters and Gold Pocket Watches.

Also, it's possible to buy Bulk Gold from vendors. However, this item is pretty rare, so the best place to get gold is from Helena.

To farm gold, simply purchase any gold items Helena has and then switch to another server. This should reset her inventory.

Tag Items For Search

Instead of having to memorize all of the items that contain gold, you can simply tag gold for search in your Pip-Boy. You can highlight any type of component by going to the junk section of your Pip-Boy and selecting any components you want to find.

It's important to note that you'll need to be holding the desired resource to tag it. So, for example, if you want to tag gold for search, then you'll need to have some gold scrap in your inventory. To tag an item, follow the steps below:

  • Hold an item that contains the resource you want to tag in your inventory
  • Scroll to the junk section in your Pip-Boy
  • Press the Component View button
  • Scroll to any resource you'd like to tag and hit Tag For Search

Anytime you look at an item that contains the resource you have tagged, a small magnifying glass icon will pop up next to the junk item's name. This just makes farming specific junk items a lot easier.

item.title: The Best RPGs On Xbox Game Pass (July 2024)
item.description:
Perhaps more than any other genre, role-playing games offer players a chance to fully immerse themselves in both a world and a story. By taking control of both a character and the quest they must embark on, fans of RPGs can experience the rewarding upward climb of progression.

Most RPGs tend to be hefty time sinks, but that only goes to show how immersive these titles can be. Luckily for those who own Xbox Game Pass, phenomenal RPG games are available at a moment’s notice. Whether someone prefers JRPGs, Western epics, or indie darlings; Microsoft's subscription service has them covered. What are the best RPGs on Game Pass ?

Updated July 8, 2024 by Mark Sammut: This month will see quite a few games launch on Game Pass, including day 1 debuts like Kunitsu-Gami: Path of the Goddess, Frostpunk 2, Dungeons of Hinterberg, and Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn. The latter two should be the best picks for RPG fans, although Flintlock seems to be a relatively traditional Souls-like. While waiting for these games to launch, players can check out a recent arrival that is also a life sim.

The games' average lengths were sourced from HowLongtoBeat.com . Also, the rankings are not determined solely by an Xbox Game Pass RPG 's quality; for instance, new additions will be initially ranked highly to increase their visibility.

1 My Time At Sandrock

Metascore: 80 (PS5)

"Role-playing" is a fairly loose term, even when its application is limited to just video games. The genre incorporates fast-paced real-time action, dialogue-driven dramas, stat-focused turn-based combat, tactical romps, open-world epics, linear adventures, and plenty more. Basically, there should be a suitable project for every situation, and Game Pass showcases this variety extremely well.

While not a typical representative by most definitions, My Time at Sandrock does an impressive job of combining RPG and life-sim elements, resulting in a package that can satisfy fans of both genres. People familiar with Pathea's previous game, My Time at Portia , should know what to expect when it comes to the 2023 release: warm visuals, well-done crafting mechanics, lively world, fun NPCs, and simple combat.

While utilizing a basic set-up of a protagonist who arrives in a new village to set up a shop, My Time at Sandrock is quite story-driven, at least by the standards of farming sims. Main quests are plentiful and meaningful, not only expanding the player's options but also progressing the world around them. Side quests are also not in short supply, and they task the protagonist with heading out of town to investigate ruins and collect resources. Honestly, My Time at Sanrock is a better life sim than an RPG, mostly due to the uninteresting combat, but the two genres elevate each other.

2 Octopath Traveler 2

Metascore: 86 (PS5)

Both Octopath Traveler entries are available on Xbox Game Pass, and together they can easily keep someone engaged for more than 100 hours. While the first game is well worth a playthrough, the sequel offers more of the same, just slightly improved in a couple of areas. Their stories, characters, and worlds are not related either, so newcomers can jump into the second game if they would rather skip its predecessor (although, again, Octopath Traveler is very good).

So, what is Octopath Traveler ? Well, these projects are essentially throwbacks to classic JRPGs from the 1990s, sort of similar to the Bravely Default games. However, they take a page from Live a Live 's playbook by focusing on character-specific storylines that are fairly standalone. That said, the playable characters are united through a central quest, and they do come across more like a genuine party than their counterparts in the first Octopath Traveler . The turn-based combat is traditional but well-executed.

3 Lords Of The Fallen

Metascore: 77

Nowadays, Soulslike games are a dime-a-dozen, and that mostly is true for Microsoft's subscription service as well. As such, Lords of the Fallen might struggle to stand out alongside some of the theme's other offerings, especially due to garnering a rather mixed reception when it debuted in 2023. While perhaps not the most highly rated option on Xbox Game Pass, Hexworks' project is arguably the exact type of project that benefits from being on the service.

Lords of the Fallen can be polarizing, particularly during its opening few hours; however, the RPG has more than a few positives in its favor. Thanks to Unreal Engine 5, it is one of the best-looking Soulslikes on the market. While a bit janky at times, the combat can be fun, and the dual-realm mechanic presents an interesting twist on the death/revival formula. The boss fights can be epic too, at least in terms of scale. Lords of the Fallen is not a must-play Soulslike in isolation, but it is a pretty easy recommendation as a Game Pass RPG.

4 Mass Effect Legendary Edition

Metascore: 90

Xbox Game Pass Ultimate owners have access to the full Mass Effect franchise. If they prefer, they can jump into the original Xbox 360 versions. These hold up reasonably well, particularly the sequels; however, Mass Effect Legendary Edition is the best way to experience Commander Shepard's story in this day and age. The package contains remastered versions of BioWare's classic trilogy, and the compilation also includes most of the DLC.

Beyond a facelift, the Legendary Edition revamps the original Mass Effect game quite extensively, bringing it more in line with the content and gameplay of its sequels. These changes make the trilogy a more consistent overall experience. Each entry is fantastic in its own right, and when combined, Mass Effect makes one of the best video game trilogies of all time.

Mass Effect: Andromeda is also on Xbox Game Pass. While not as good as the trilogy, it is still decent.

5 Persona 3 Reload

Metascore: 86

Persona 5 's shadow looms large over Atlus' entire franchise, and its fingerprints can be seen in Persona 3 Reload , Atlus' 2024 remake of 2006's PS2 JRPG. However, this iteration is still 100% Persona 3 , retaining the original's dark atmosphere, fantastic storytelling, and Tartarus. In a series that has produced almost nothing but stellar games, P3 stands as a genuine contender for its crowning achievement, and Reload shows the classic JRPG all the respect it deserves.

Blending dungeon-crawling with social sim aspects, P3R strikes an outstanding balance that satisfies both genres' needs in a way that ensures they complement each other. During the day, players get to live the life of a Japanese high school student, which involves attending class and hanging out with friends. These sections are the campaign's beating heart, granting depth to the characters while also weaving a powerful tale that tackles mostly mature themes.

At night, players lead a party into an intense dungeon crawling with Persona, creatures that can be added to the protagonist's arsenal. As a monster-collecting game, P3R offers a wide and impressive roster of candidates, and the game expects players to be constantly cycling through new party members by either catching Persona or using the fusion system. While the JRPG's turn-based combat is fairly traditional for the genre, P3R elevates the action through a fantastic presentation and supporting mechanics that inject an element of strategy into battles.

6 The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim Special Edition

Metascore: 82

Skyrim has essentially ruled the open-world RPG roost since its unsubtle and highly-anticipated release in 2011 — that alone should be enough to showcase its necessity for any RPG enthusiast's repertoire. While it can be safely accused of shedding the deeper mechanical complexities of its predecessors, the cold fact of the matter is that Bethesda did more than a few things right.

Skyrim preserves the franchise's legacy of beautifully designed open worlds filled with enough content to keep even the most dedicated gamers busy for years while expanding the scope of its audience exponentially. It's practically gaming's equivalent to required reading at this point, and it's not hard to see why.

Morrowind and Elder Scrolls Online are also on Xbox Game Pass.

7 Dragon Age: Origins

Metascore: 86

The addition of EA Play to Xbox Game Pass Ultimate brought with it plenty of great RPGs, including some of the best trilogies in gaming. Dragon Age: Origins is the definition of an epic; a grandiose adventure filled with political intrigue, narrative depth, complex combat, and unforgettable characters.

The game is at its best on PC, but the Xbox 360 version is perfectly playable. While somewhat dated by today's standards, Origins has aged beautifully in the areas that matter the most: world-building, storytelling, and character-build variety. The sequels are also worth checking out, but Dragon Age arguably peaked with its first entry, setting a standard that few fantasy RPGs have come close to replicating.

Dragon Age 2 and Dragon Age: Inquisition are also on Xbox Game Pass.

8 Palworld (Game Preview)

Blends Multiple Genres To Create Something New & Exciting

2024 has produced a couple of major AAA games, but arguably none of them attracted as much attention as Palworld . While still in early access (or Game Preview on Xbox), Pocket Pair's project is already in fine shape, offering a fairly robust and complete experience that still has plenty of room for expansion. As Baldur's Gate 3 proved in 2023, a lengthy spell in early access could be the difference between a good and fantastic game, and the latter could easily be used to describe Palworld in its current form.

Before its release, the project was labeled as Pokemon with guns, a descriptor that, while accurate, sells the project's scope short. Palworld is a survival open-world game with monster-collecting, base building, third-person shooting, RPG mechanics, and co-op. On the surface, it might seem like Pocket Pair is trying to reach too many audiences, but the pieces come together to create a surprisingly cohesive whole. Palworld is addictive, and while there is not much of a story, the basic gameplay loop is more than fun enough to keep players engaged for dozens upon dozens of hours.

9 Crusader Kings 3

Metascore: 83

If strategy games can seem inapproachable to newcomers, then grand strategy titles must seem absolutely foreign. Crusader Kings 3 represents the subgenre at its best, and it is arguably Paradox's crowning achievement, a statement that is not made lightly. While needing no introduction to players fond of these sorts of games, CK3 might seem too dense for people who have yet to dip their toes in the universe of grand strategies; however, although not easy to master, the game is among the most accessible options on the market.

More importantly, CK3 is a proper RPG that follows a family tree as the members' decisions shape their kingdoms and the rest of the world. Along with fairly standard grand strategy mechanics, Paradox emphasizes each character's personality, encouraging players to properly role-play as their rulers. Unlike most other entries in this subgenre, CK3 is primarily about the individuals that mold history through their relationships, biases, flaws, and strengths.

10 Tales Of Arise

Metascore: 87

Even if it is not as synonymous with JRPGs as Final Fantasy or Dragon Quest , Bandai Namco's Tales is one of the genre's most beloved franchises, and an argument could be made that it is the definitive action property. While fairly consistent in terms of quality, a few entries stand out from the crowd, and Tales of Arise is one of the best games in the series. The 2021 release also serves as a great introduction to the IP, and since the story is not connected to any previous releases, newcomers can jump into this project without hesitation.

Telling a fairly major story that tackles themes of discrimination and oppression, Arise blends strong storytelling with addictive combat, likable characters, and a fair amount of secondary content. While the campaign is quite long, new settings and mechanics are introduced frequently enough to ensure things remain interesting throughout, and all the playable characters are unique and come with learning curves.

11 Lies Of P

Metascore: 84

Soulslike games belong to their own genre, but they still fall under the action RPG umbrella. Lies of P is an inspired take on the Soulsborne formula, even if its core mechanics do not stray too far from the beaten path. Cast as Pinocchio, players will find themselves exploring Krat, a Gothic fallen utopia that has become overrun by deadly puppets who come in a wide range of shapes and sizes.

Unlike some other entries in the genre, Lies of P has a fixed protagonist and does not offer too many customization options, at least not in the opening few hours. Players can select from three combat styles, and they unlock new weapons at a steady but not overwhelming pace. Importantly, Lies of P nails its combat and enemy design, offering fast-paced and aggressive action that demands players master all the game's mechanics, particularly parrying.

12 Diablo 4

Metascore: 91

Blizzard's Diablo 4 is a weird beast. The hack and slash RPG attracted near-universal praise at launch and was regarded as a solid evolution for the franchise. However, the game's reputation declined quite quickly after that point, with a few subsequent updates being viewed as a step back rather than a leap forward. Nowadays, the RPG exists in a strange space where it feels somewhat like old news, although Diablo 4 's Loot Reborn patch was a huge move in the right direction.

Polarizing as it might be, Diablo 4 is nevertheless massive. Except for a more expansive open-world and a couple of touches, Blizzard's action RPG does not reinvent the wheel, instead opting to offer a straightforward combat-loot-combat loop. The story is fine but nothing special, and it largely exists to keep people busy until they reach the endgame. The combat is simplistic as well, but it is satisfying in a shut-off-your-brain type of way. Unsurprisingly, the game floods players with loot, which provides a small dopamine hit every time. For all its divisive elements, at its core, Diablo 4 is a pretty good action RPG that has the potential to be better. If someone is on the fence about trying this sequel, they can now jump on board thanks to Xbox Game Pass.

13 Cassette Beasts

Metascore: 84 (PC)

Xbox Game Pass has a couple of monster-collecting games. Those titles can keep someone busy for months on end, but Atlus' series has some competition. Initially launching on PC before making its way to consoles, Cassette Beasts is a fantastic indie project that takes inspiration from the likes of Pokemon , particularly the older isometric entries, while also crafting a unique voice that sets it apart from its peers. Arriving at a peculiar island called New Wirral, players are quickly greeted by a ranger who tells them about their ability to transform into beasts, which they will need to do to survive the habitat's wildlife.

Cassette Beasts ' title gives its monster-taming mechanic away: players "catch" creatures by recording them on a cassette tape. If successful, the protagonist and their human partners will be able to transform into them during battles. Set in a vibrant and diverse open-world, the game offers a creative modernization of this RPG subgenre's typical formula, and it even manages to incorporate a pretty interesting story. Along with the main campaign, players have quite a few side activities to keep them busy.

14 Darkest Dungeon

Metascore: 83 (PS4)

Darkest Dungeon is a cutthroat game that takes no prisoners. Players inherit a mansion sitting on top of a strange dungeon, so they hire heroes to explore the creepy labyrinth within. Like most RPGs, these characters come in a variety of classes and can be leveled up; unlike most RPGs, death is permanent in Darkest Dungeon . There is nothing quite as infuriating as watching a powerful hero meet their maker, never to be seen again.

Red Hook's game uses a turn-based combat system that centers around parties of four characters. While exploring the dungeon, players have to monitor the heroes' stress levels along with a myriad of other mechanics. It is quite a challenge.

15 Sea Of Stars

Metascore: 89

August and September 2023 produced two of 2023's biggest RPGs: Baldur's Gate 3 and Starfield . Most indie projects released around the same time as these games were destined to be overshadowed, and that's without even mentioning Armored Core 6 and Lies of P . Therefore, the fact that Sea of Stars still managed to make a splash speaks to its quality. Inspired by '90s JRPGs, Sabotage crafted a gem that pays tribute to its influential ancestors without fully anchoring itself to them.

Set on an island, Sea of Stars follows two heroes tasked with defeating a spreading corruption. On the surface, this premise might sound generic, but it is all about the execution. Not only does the lengthy storyline take a few genuine risks as it progresses, but it is also packed with endearing characters and fun optional content. The turn-based combat system is pretty great too.

16 Stardew Valley

Metascore: 89

Launching in 2016, Stardew Valley has blossomed into one of gaming's most enduring farming sims. The indie game comes packed with so much content and freedom that two people could wind up having completely different experiences. Whether planning out a year's worth of farming or sparking a romance with one of the NPCs, Stardew Valley is incredibly immersive.

Offering endearing visuals, expansive customization options, and a lot to discover, this game will keep somebody playing for months on end. For those looking for a title that doesn't prioritize combat but is still quite challenging in places, Stardew Valley is a stellar pick.

17 Remnant 2

Metascore: 85

Remnant: From the Ashes and its 2023 sequel were added to Xbox Game Pass at the same time, allowing players to experience all the currently available content at the click of a button. Gunfire's IP is known as the third-person shooter Soulslike, a well-earned reputation since it is undoubtedly the best series that combines the two genres without limiting gunplay to a secondary mechanic. Similar to Lies of P , Remnant takes many ideas from RPGs; in fact, these two games are arguably more conventional entries into that genre. Remnant: From the Ashes is very good and a fine entry point into this universe, but its sequel is slightly better.

Featuring a lengthy campaign that is designed to be replayed, Remnant 2 sends players to multiple words that are overrun with the Rot. Once at one of these locations, players need to explore the overworld while searching for dungeons that conclude with boss fights. The latter are procedurally generated, so they should be different from playthrough to playthrough. At the start of a run, players pick from a few available archetypes that act as classes, and these are quite different from each other. Players are also granted a fair range of customization options that revolve around both stats and equipment, allowing them to tweak their character to suit their preferences.

18 Dead Island 2

Metascore: 76

Dead Island 2 is primarily an action game with RPG elements, so it might not be exactly what every fan of the genre is craving; however, as the project is generally described as an action-RPG, a recommendation is warranted. More importantly, the 2023 game is just fun, and sometimes that is the only thing that matters. Featuring an awesome and gory combat system, Dead Island 2 lets players rampage through a post-apocalyptic Los Angeles, arming them with a colorful assortment of weapons to ensure they can gleefully tear zombies to shreds. The minute-to-minute gameplay is a blast, and the campaign does not overstay its welcome either.

In terms of RPG mechanics, Dead Island 2 utilizes cards for unlocking and improving skills. While serviceable, this process is not extremely exciting nor does it provide too much wiggle room for experimentation. Still, players can customize their characters to an extent, and the game includes a traditional level-up system.

19 Wasteland 3

Metascore: 84

All three Wasteland games are available on Xbox Game Pass, and each one improves on the last. Wasteland 3 is a challenging strategy turn-based RPG reminiscent of classic Fallout titles, and it comes with a dark sense of humor and a desire to constantly challenge players with difficult decisions.

A deep and flexible combat system should keep the game feeling fresh throughout its considerable length, while Wasteland 3 's story and world-building are second to none. Co-op is also possible for those who want to travel through Colorado with a friend.

20 Fable 2

Metascore: 89

Released in 2008, Fable 2 returns players to the wonderful world of Albion. All three games in the series have their positives and negatives, but Fable 2 is the most complete and satisfying experience in the trilogy. Players roam an enchanting realm as they set out to carve their own paths and highlight their unique quirks. Albion reacts to the player's actions, developing to match the choices made throughout the adventure.

Fable 2 takes place in a living, breathing world that empowers users but also doesn't forget the deeds (or misdeeds) they perform. Although not amazing, the real-time combat system is serviceable and offers enough variety to remain engaging throughout the campaign.

Fable and Fable 3 are also on Xbox Game Pass.

item.title: Disney Pixel RPG Announced
item.description:
Highlights

  • Disney Pixel RPG is a new mobile game featuring iconic Disney characters.
  • Developed by GungHo Online Entertainment, the game combines auto-battling mechanics and avatar customization.
  • Disney Pixel RPG will soft-launch in Japan on September 9, while its global availability details have yet to be confirmed.

A new mobile game called Disney Pixel RPG has been announced. The free-to-play title promises to offer players a chance to engage with a wide variety of iconic Disney characters in a picturesque setting.

Although Disney occasionally makes its own games, licensing its IPs to third parties still accounts for the bulk of the entertainment giant's activities in the gaming industry. In recent years, that strategy has largely been focused on live-service titles like Disney Dreamlight Valley .

Disney Pixel RPG Soft-Launching in September 2024

Yet another such project has just been unveiled in the form of Disney Pixel RPG . The newly announced game is in the works at Japanese developer GungHo Online Entertainment, known for its work on the Grandia and Puzzles and Dragons franchises, among dozens of other properties. Disney Pixel RPG will attempt to tap into the studio's mobile expertise, having been envisioned as a casual role-playing game that combines iconic Disney characters with auto-battling mechanics and avatar customization, among other features.

The game itself is scheduled to soft-launch in Japan on September 9, 2024. Its preview version will be available on both Android and iOS devices. GungHo confirmed that the upcoming title will be optimized for tablets, making full use of their extra screen real estate rather than rendering in a letterbox format. Japanese gamers who pre-register for Disney Pixel RPG have a chance to win a ¥10,000 Amazon gift card later this summer. GungHo has yet to confirm that its newly unveiled game is planned to launch beyond its home country, but that seems like a plausible scenario, not least because a lot of Disney Pixel RPG promotional materials are already presented in English.

Disney Pixel RPG Pre-Registrations

  • Google Play Store
  • iOS App Store

The list of characters that have already been confirmed as part of the game's cast include Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck, Goofy, Ariel, Maleficent, Baymax, Stitch, Sleeping Beauty, Winnie-the-Pooh, and Genie from Aladdin . The game itself promises "slapstick strategy battles" that will require players to compose teams of three characters. Aside from a story mode, Disney Pixel RPG will also offer Expeditions, resource-gathering quests meant to run in between playing sessions. A hub area of some sort will also be part of the package, having apparently been envisioned as a venue where players will be able to interact with their party. While the specifics of its character collection mechanics are yet to be revealed, Disney Pixel RPG seems to have all the makings of a gacha game.

The 8-bit RPG may not be the only Disney-licensed title to make its way to Android and iOS devices in the near future. According to one recent report, Disney is currently also working on a new mobile game with Sega.

item.title: Animal Crossing's Fishing Tourney, Bug-Off Have an Obvious Next Step to Take
item.description:
The Animal Crossing games have many events involving active participation, but there are two that breed healthy sportsmanship and are a ton of fun to take part in. With their current iteration known as C.J.'s Fishing Tourney and Flick's Bug-Off Competition, these contests have become a popular mainstay in the franchise as they reward players for simply doing two daily activities. As great as the two already are, they can still be improved and the next Animal Crossing has a chance to do that by adding one simple feature.

Animal Crossing: New Horizons ' take on the Fishing Tourney and Bug-Off contest shows that there's a way to make players compete against each other or themselves. Both events require participants to capture as many creatures as possible within three minutes to gain points. While many usually aim for the rewards obtained by getting high enough scores, some take on a more personal challenge of seeing just how many creatures they can acquire within the time limit. Since it's shown that players are willing to do such a task, Nintendo could consider adding an online leaderboard for both events. This can elevate the status of both competitions and give players a bigger reason to participate in them.

Why the Fishing Tourney and Bug-off Should Have a Leaderboard

Having an online leaderboard seems like a great new feature for the next Animal Crossing and its bug and fish-catching competitions, assuming both stick to the mechanics of New Horizons . A few reasons why Nintendo should consider implementing it in the franchise's next mainline entry include:

  • Seeing the highest number of creatures people have caught around the world will give players an incentive to one-up them, further popularizing both events
  • Nintendo can promote seasonal online tournaments with players obtaining limited-time items
  • The leaderboards can knit the franchise's community closer together, prompting them to discuss and engage more with one another

If online leaderboards are implemented, then it's very likely that more players will look forward to both contests more than ever. Constantly checking who's at the top and trying to become the best will give players an achievement they'll continuously reach for, ensuring the game thrives. This is the one big change for the next Animal Crossing that Nintendo should strongly consider, as it seems like a simple yet effective step in promoting and improving both events.

The Other Benefits of Having Leaderboards in Animal Crossing

Regardless of the next Animal Crossing 's setting, it will likely still have events with a scoring system like the Bug-off or Fishing Tourney. If an online leaderboard can successfully expand the popularity of such competitions, then there is a chance that future installments will have more of them. Nintendo can take it a step further from capturing as many bugs or fish as possible to contests where players gather scattered materials in the shortest amount of time. Such ideas can give Nintendo extra opportunities to promote the franchise while giving its community more things to look forward to and do.

Having a leaderboard can also help the longevity of every mainline entry in the franchise. The next Animal Crossing has a golden opportunity to implement the online feature as it's a way to ensure that people will keep playing even after achieving the other in-game objectives. Many try to show they're the best at something and will constantly try to outdo anyone to prove they are. With an online leaderboard, these people have a reason to give it their all in any contest to obtain bragging rights. Since it can be a never-ending cycle with players constantly trying to outdo one another, it ensures the game continues to thrive potentially even after its foreseen lifespan.

While there's no telling what's next for Animal Crossing after New Horizons , there's hope that Nintendo will consider adding leaderboards for future entries. Other than benefiting the Bug-Off and Fishing Tourney events, it may also lead to newer content that can take the franchise to greater heights.
